summary: A forwarded email from Mark Anthony Taylor to Mel Stride, Chairman of the UK Treasury Select Committee, alleging a cover-up regarding Jes Staley's connections to Jeffrey Epstein and blackmail of Parliament and the judiciary. The email accuses various UK officials and institutions of suppressing evidence and failing to investigate.

persons.name: Mark Anthony Taylor
persons.context: Author alleging cover-up of Jes Staley's connections to Jeffrey Epstein and blackmail of Parliament/judiciary; claims his friend was murdered for exposing the story.

persons.name: Mel Stride
persons.role: Chairman of the UK Treasury Select Committee
persons.context: Recipient of the email; accused of personal responsibility for the TSC withholding key legal evidence from ongoing inquiries.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.role: Former CEO of Barclays, former JP Morgan executive
persons.context: Central figure accused of being part of Jeffrey Epstein's blackmail ring and attending child-rape parties; subject of investigations by FBI, FCA, and PRA.

persons.name: Andrew Bailey
persons.role: Head of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
persons.context: Accused of refusing to investigate Jes Staley and being corrupted; mentioned as being considered for top job at Bank of England despite FCA's low approval rating.

persons.name: Lisa Osofsky
persons.role: Head of the Serious Fraud Office (SFO)
persons.context: Accused of explicitly refusing to investigate Jes Staley after being supplied with FOIA responses.

persons.name: Judge Worster
persons.context: Alleged to have served restraining orders against the author, blocking truth about Staley; questioned about taking a bribe or following TSC orders to gag the author.

persons.name: Ian Burnett
persons.context: Suggested by the author that if Staley bribed a judge, Burnett would need to be 'in the loop'; referenced in context of Lord Etherton implying Burnett was a paedophile.

persons.name: Lord Etherton
persons.role: Presumably a member of the judiciary
persons.context: Mentioned as having implied that Lord Chief Justice Ian Burnett was a paedophile.

persons.name: Lord Adrian PIE Fulford
persons.role: Presumably a member of the judiciary
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Ian Burnett works with, described as 'highly suspect' by the author.

persons.name: Paul Kernaghan
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Ian Burnett works with, described as 'highly suspect' by the author.

persons.name: Roger Jenkins
persons.role: Unspecified, appears connected to Barclays/JP Morgan
persons.context: Asked if the TSC bothered to have the FCA investigate him, as he also appears to have gone to Epstein's child-rape parties.

persons.name: Maciej Wenerski
persons.role: Civil servant handling FOIA requests for TSC
persons.context: Replied to the author's earlier email a month later, handling it as a FOIA request.

persons.name: Theo Clarke
persons.role: MP, constituency MP for the author
persons.context: Copied on the original December 2019 email to the TSC.

persons.name: Mark Carney
persons.role: Governor of the Bank of England
persons.context: Mentioned as being investigated along with Andrew Bailey for the LC&F scandal.

persons.name: Elizabeth Gloster
persons.role: Dame, presumably a legal or regulatory figure
persons.context: Copied on the email, likely in a regulatory or investigative capacity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central to the alleged blackmail ring; his emails are cited as key evidence that should have led to Jes Staley's dismissal.

connections.description: Staley is alleged to have been part of Epstein's blackmail ring and to have attended Epstein's child-rape parties.
Both are implied to have attended Epstein's child-rape parties, connecting them through alleged involvement with Epstein.
Bailey, as head of FCA, is accused of refusing to investigate Staley, suggesting a possible cover-up or corruption.
Osofsky, as head of SFO, is accused of refusing to investigate Staley, suggesting a possible cover-up or corruption.
Worster served two restraining orders against Taylor, effectively gagging him from publicly validating the truth about Staley.
Mentioned as working together, with the author implying this association is 'highly suspect'.
Mentioned as working together, with the author implying this association is 'highly suspect'.

events.title: Initial email to TSC regarding Epstein blackmail
events.description: Mark Anthony Taylor sent an initial email to the Treasury Select Committee and his MP Theo Clarke regarding Epstein's blackmail of Parliament and the Judiciary.

events.title: Follow-up email alleging cover-up
events.description: Taylor sends a follow-up email to Mel Stride, alleging a cover-up by the TSC, FCA, and SFO regarding Jes Staley's connections to Epstein.

events.title: Friend's murder for exposing Epstein-Staley story
events.description: Taylor claims his friend may have been murdered in 2017 for exposing the Epstein and Staley story.

events.title: Epstein emails should have led to Staley's dismissal
events.description: According to the author, blackmail emails from Epstein in 2015 should have been enough to have Jes Staley dismissed from his position.

locations: Kalamata Billington Lane Derrington Stafford ST18 9LR
keyFacts: The author alleges that the UK Treasury Select Committee (TSC) has suppressed key information regarding Jes Staley's connections to Jeffrey Epstein for almost five years.
Andrew Bailey (FCA) and Lisa Osofsky (SFO) are accused of explicitly refusing to investigate Jes Staley after being provided with FOIA responses.
The author claims his friend may have been murdered in 2017 for exposing the Epstein and Staley story, and this was presented as evidence to Judge Worster.
Judge Worster served restraining orders against the author, which blocked the truth about Staley from being validated in a legal document.
The email suggests that Jeffrey Epstein blackmailed Parliament to place Jes Staley in his position and to secure the appointments of Andrew Bailey and Lisa Osofsky.
